abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            with project sustainability likely. The overall performance
            of both the World Bank and the Borrower are rated
            satisfactory. Among the lessons learned from this project
            are the following: 1) Ensure leveraging and mutual support
            between investment and adjustment lending. The use of both
            vehicles to maintain trade reform momentum has shown to be
            effective in the ITIP and the Fiscal Consolidation and
            Competitive Growth Adjustment Loan. The backsliding in the
            original reforms achieved under the former operation, which
            substantially reduced technical barriers to trade, was
            stemmed and reversed by the latter. 2) Ensure early private
            sector participation in project design. Very active
            involvement of private sector stakeholders in the design of
            regulatory reforms and new institutional arrangements is
            essential and can provide strong continuity to maintain
            Project objectives and implementation momentum in the midst
            of high turnover at government levels. 3) Provide for
            explicit program outreach to regions and excluded groups. 4)
            Enforce regulatory reforms with stronger institutional
            support. 5) Ensure regulatory reforms benefit smaller firms.
            6) Leverage broadly the successes of learning and innovation
            programs. 7) Evaluate learning and innovation programs
            earlier and later. Early monitoring and evaluation of
            subprojects was found under the Project to be a sound tool
            for program management and policy adjustments to ensure
            proper targeting. Economic evaluation work should also be
            scheduled for 1-2 years following the completion of
            disbursements to better determine the full impact. 8)
            Evaluate the fiscal impact of learning and innovation
            programs. 9) Adjust policies to improve the impact of
            learning and innovation programs on microbusiness.  10) Use
            "competitiveness" as a process tool for policy
            reform. The competitiveness diagnostics carried out under
            the Program were one important impetus for structuring
            senior government attention to this subject and increasing
            public-private collaboration around this thematic.
